Hurricanes and typhoons are both tropical cyclones, which are rotating systems of clouds and thunderstorms that form over warm ocean waters. The main difference between them is their location.

Hurricanes typically form in the Atlantic Ocean or the eastern Pacific Ocean, while typhoons are formed in the western Pacific Ocean. 

The formation of these storms requires certain conditions. They form over warm ocean waters with temperatures of at least 27°C (80°F), which provide the necessary fuel for the storm. The warm water evaporates, which causes moist air to rise and create an area of low pressure. This low pressure draws in more air and causes it to spin. 

Once the storm begins to rotate, it can intensify rapidly if other conditions are favorable, such as low wind shear and high humidity. The storm's winds pick up speed and its central pressure drops, leading to stronger winds and more intense rainfall.

In summary, hurricanes and typhoons are both tropical cyclones that form over warm ocean waters due to a combination of low pressure, warm water, and other favorable conditions. The only difference between them is the location where they form.
